Melbourne, Victoria, Australia
Secure attachment in early childhood is important for wellbeing throughout life. Music interventions show promise for supporting early parent–child relationships; however, their effects on attachment security are unclear as few music intervention evaluations have measured attachment outcomes. This systematic literature review aimed to synthesize published empirical literature examining the effects of music interventions on relationship quality between typically developing children aged birth to 5 years old and their parents. The study aimed to: (1) establish whether music interventions were associated with changes in attachment-related outcomes; (2) identify music intervention

characteristics likely to support secure attachment; and (3) elucidate processes through which music techniques may have contributed to attachment-related changes. Included interventions focused on the parent–child dyad, involved a substantial music component delivered by a music therapist or an allied health professional, and assessed and/ or described relationship outcome/s. A  total of 23 studies describing 15 unique interventions met criteria for inclusion and represented approximately 808–815 parent–child dyads. Mothers were the most common caregivers. All interventions demonstrated some effectiveness, including in attachment-related outcomes such as bonding, emotional co-regulation, and parental sensitivity. All interventions involved singing, suggesting it may be especially suitable for supporting parent– child attachment; other music techniques used included instrument playing and movement to music. Findings suggested that music interventions may facilitate attachment-related changes through intervening in psychological processes, including parental sensitivity, reflective functioning, and emotional co-regulation. Future research should develop music interventions aiming specifically to support attachment quality, and music intervention evaluations should use validated attachment assessments and longitudinal study designs.

Parent–child attachment refers to a child accessing their parent as a “safe haven” to provide comfort when they are distressed, and a “secure base” from which to explore their environment. A secure attachment develops when a parent consistently meets their child’s needs in these areas, while an insecure attachment develops when a parent does not meet some or all of these needs reliably (Ainsworth et al., 1978; Bowlby, 1969; Powell et al., 2014). Parent–child attachment quality can be influenced by proximal and distal factors, such as the parent’s history with their own caregivers and environmental stressors (e.g., parental mental illness; Fonagy et al., 1991; Sroufe, 2005; Tronick, 2007). Insecure attachment (which encompasses ambivalent, avoidant and disorganized subtypes; Ainsworth et al., 1978; Main & Solomon, 1986) in early childhood is associated with challenges in adulthood (e.g., mental health difficulties; Sroufe, 2005); therefore, interventions that support attachment security in early childhood are warranted.

Parent–child attachment security is influenced by various factors, including parental sensitivity and parental reflective functioning (PRF). Parental sensitivity refers to the parent’s level of “contingent responsiveness” (Nicholls & Kirkland, 1996, p. 59; i.e., the appropriateness, timing, and consistency of their responses) to their child’s needs (Ainsworth et al., 1978; Bigelow et al., 2010; Nicholls & Kirkland, 1996). PRF refers to the parent’s ability to understand and reflect on their child’s internal states and engage in observation and self-reflection of their own internal experience. It is theorized to enable a parent to understand their child’s inner world and thereby respond sensitively to their needs (Fonagy et al., 1991; Slade, 2007). For example, a mother who interprets her infant’s crying as a reflection of distress may respond by soothing her infant. Parent–child attachment is also influenced by affect attunement, which refers to parental mirroring, imitation and/or matching of the child’s internal states in a way that shows the child that their parent has resonated with their felt experience (Stern, 1985), and emotional co-regulation, which involves the mutual regulation of affective states by parent and child. Emotional co-regulation encompasses shared positive affect and repair of negative affect (e.g., a parent reconnecting with their child and soothing them; Guo et  al., 2015; Schore, 2001; Tronick, 2007).
Music interventions have features which make them suited to supporting parent–child attachment (Edwards, 2011; Perry, 2009). Parents can attune to and co-regulate their child’s emotional states using musical elements such as rhythm and pitch (Malloch, 1999; Stern, 1985; Trehub et  al., 1997). Aspects of music (e.g., rhythm) can provide “patterned, repetitive neural input” (Perry, 2009, p. 243), which is proposed to support the regulation of the lower order brain structures often affected by early attachment problems (Perry, 2009). For example, a parent could provide patterned input by singing and rhythmically patting their infant in time with their singing. Singing can also improve self-regulation and social engagement through inducing changes in affect and physiology (Porges, 2011). These features of music may enhance co-regulation through improving self-regulation (Perry, 2009; Porges, 2011; Schore, 2001). Additionally, music-based parenting interventions are reported to be more acceptable to parents than other forms of therapy (e.g., behavioral therapy; Abad & Williams,

2007). High acceptability of music interventions may facilitate parental engagement in intervention, which could potentially lead to greater relationship improvements than interventions with poorer parental engagement (Hackworth et al., 2018).
The potential of music interventions for supporting parent– child attachment is evident. However, it is not possible to conclude whether music interventions increase attachment security, as no studies have evaluated the efficacy of music interventions using valid and reliable observational methods to assess parent–child attachment quality (e.g., the Strange Situation Procedure; Ainsworth et  al., 1978; Main & Solomon, 1986). Nonetheless, studies have evaluated the effects of music interventions on attachment-related outcomes (e.g., parental sensitivity; Nicholson et  al., 2008). Examining studies which explore music intervention effects on attachment-related outcomes may enable researchers to draw preliminary conclusions about whether music interventions may increase attachment security.
A systematic review of studies evaluating whether music interventions support parent–child attachment quality has not yet been undertaken, possibly because no studies have examined the impact of music interventions on attachment security. However, some studies have reviewed available theoretical and research literature about music interventions to support parent–child attachment. A descriptive literature review examining music therapy for children up to 5 years old found no peer-reviewed articles exploring music intervention effects on parent–child attachment, suggesting that there was limited or no empirical research on attachmentspecific music interventions from 1990 to 2012 (Tuomi et  al., 2017). Other authors theorized about using music techniques to support parent–child attachment, although they did not systematically review music intervention evaluations (Creighton, 2011; Edwards, 2011).
There is currently no evidence available to definitively establish whether music interventions improve attachment security. Therefore, the present study focused on synthesizing available literature exploring music intervention characteristics, attachmentrelated outcomes, and change processes during music interventions. Change processes were defined by Elliott (2010) as processes during therapy and changes occurring within clients throughout therapy that contribute to outcomes. The aim of the review was

to locate and synthesize peer-reviewed literature evaluating the impact of music interventions on parent–child relationships for typically developing children aged from birth to 5 years old. The specific research aims were: (1) to determine whether the existing evidence suggested changes in attachment-related outcomes due to music interventions; (2) to identify characteristics of music interventions likely to support early attachment security; and (3) to describe the processes through which particular music techniques may have contributed to attachment-related parenting and parent– child relationship changes.
Method
Study Design
A systematic review was undertaken to locate peer-reviewed primary publications evaluating the impact of music interventions on parent–child relationships with typically developing children aged from birth to 5 years old. The PRISMA-P (2015) checklist (Moher et al., 2015) informed the design and methodology of the systematic review protocol and reporting of study findings. Given the small number of studies overall, various research designs (e.g., qualitative, quantitative, and mixed methods) were included, comprising a convergent integrated approach to data extraction (Lizarondo et  al., 2020). Unlike most systematic reviews using a convergent integrated approach, data was not transformed, and findings were presented as a narrative synthesis integrating both quantitative and qualitative findings (Heyvaert et  al., 2017). The first author oversaw the narrative synthesis process in consultation with the second and third authors. All included studies were undertaken in real-world rather than laboratory settings and many studies did not involve stringently manualized or standardized intervention protocols, suggesting that the body of research more closely resembled effectiveness than efficacy studies overall (Singal et al., 2014). Thus, the authors determined that it was appropriate to conduct quality and effectiveness assessments to explore whether music interventions improve attachment-related outcomes. The quality and effectiveness assessments were not intended to establish intervention effectiveness for improving attachment security; therefore, the authors determined that it was not necessary to conduct interrater reliability.

sections.heading: Search Strategy and Inclusion Criteria
sections.text:
The first and second authors developed the search strategy and the inclusion criteria. Search terms were developed from initial database searches and included key terms in four areas: music or singing, caregivers, children, and relationship quality including attachment. Terms were refined and those not returning records were excluded (e.g., “toddler”, “father*”, “caregiver*”, “family,” and “families”). Final search terms and Boolean operators were: (music OR singing) AND (attachment OR bond* OR respons* OR relationship* OR interaction*) AND (parent* OR mother*) AND (child* OR infant* OR bab*).
Databases likely to include music interventions were searched, particularly PsycInfo, Scopus, EbscoHost (indexing RILM Abstracts of Music Literature and Music Index) and selected databases from Proquest (refer to Supplementary Material for a list of the databases searched from Proquest). Additional records were located by mining the reference lists of identified articles and other closely related articles. The first author conducted searches and screening during December 2019, first by title, then abstract and finally full text, with articles not meeting inclusion criteria at each stage being excluded. Decisions about inclusion were discussed with the second and third authors for 20 records where decisions were unclear to the first author. No date range was applied and searches were limited to peer-reviewed publications in English. Gray literature, commentary pieces, and clinical reflections, which did not evaluate an intervention, were excluded.
Participants Studies were included if participants were dyads comprising a parent and a typically developing child. “Parent” refers to a child’s primary caregiver, including biological parents, foster carers, adoptive parents, or other caregivers (e.g., grandparent). Studies with antenatal samples were included if therapist and/or parent intervention delivery continued postnatally and studies combining parent–fetal and postpartum parent–infant bonding were included if postpartum findings were reported. Studies reporting caregiver mental illness, hospitalization, and/or domestic violence were included because the focus was on relationship quality, irrespective of potential contributors to relationship difficulties.
Studies involving a child without their parent, children with a mean age over 5 years old, and/or children with additional needs

were excluded. Children with additional needs were defined as children who had developmental delays, physical and/or intellectual disabilities, medical conditions, physical injuries, or were in hospital (e.g., premature infants). Samples including typically developing children and children with additional needs were only included if findings were presented separately for each group.
Interventions Music interventions were defined by the researchers as the intentional use of music techniques (e.g., singing, songwriting, playing instruments, or music-assisted relaxation) for therapeutic purposes. To meet review criteria, interventions primarily focused on music techniques, and the study authors clearly outlined the music techniques and described how they were used. Interventions aimed to improve parenting or the parent–child relationship, interaction, bond, or attachment quality with a focus on the parent–child dyad, even in group sessions or with other family members present. Included studies reported outcomes quantitatively (e.g., questionnaires) or qualitatively (e.g., parent interviews).
Interventionists Intervention delivery could be by (a) a qualified music therapist (henceforth, music therapist); (b) an allied health professional (e.g., nurse, psychologist); (c) a parent delivering an intervention to their child after receiving training, which clearly instructed the parent about when and how to deliver the intervention outside of sessions, from an allied health professional or music therapist (i.e., parent-mediated interventions); or (d) an allied health professional or music therapist with another professional (e.g., musician, researcher). Interventions primarily led by other individuals, including but not limited to musicians or teachers, were excluded to ensure that the interventionist had appropriate training to deliver a therapeutic intervention which aimed to improve parent–child relationship quality.

sections.heading: Quality Assessment
sections.text:
The first author assessed methodological rigor of included studies, with some assistance from the second author, using the JBI (2020) Critical Appraisal tools. Studies using a mixed-methods design were assessed using tools appropriate to each study component, and studies incorporating elements of multiple designs were analyzed using the most appropriate tool (refer to the Supplementary
Table 1 for an outline of the Critical Appraisal tool/s used to evaluate each study). Each quality assessment involved responding

to questions about the study design with one of the following responses: Yes, No, Unclear or Not Applicable (refer to JBI, 2020 for the questions on each Critical Appraisal tool). Each study was classified as Weak, Medium, or Strong based on the percentage of study components present (i.e., “Yes” responses) which demonstrate a strong design. The first and second authors developed the following classifications: Weak (<25%), Weak to Medium (25–30%), Medium (31–69%), Medium to Strong (70–75%), and Strong (>75%; refer to the Supplementary Table 1 for the score and percentage of each quality assessment). Percentages rather than numerical criteria were used because the number of study components identified as representing a strong design differed depending on the Critical Appraisal tool.
Strength of evidence of quantitative studies was determined using the JBI Levels of Evidence for Effectiveness, in which Level 1 (experimental designs) was the strongest and Level 5 (expert opinion and bench research) was the weakest. Strength of evidence of qualitative studies was determined using the JBI Levels of Evidence for Meaningfulness, wherein Level 1 (qualitative or mixed-methods systematic review) was the strongest, and Level 5 (expert opinion) was the weakest (Joanna Briggs Institute Levels of Evidence and Grades of Recommendation Working Party, 2013). The quality of the body of evidence overall was rated based on the quality assessments of individual studies.

sections.heading: Effectiveness Assessment
sections.text:
The first author completed the effectiveness assessments, although questions about the application of criteria were discussed with the second and third authors. The first and second authors developed the following criteria for rating study effectiveness for improving the parent–child relationship. Qualitative and case study ratings were based on “clinically significant” changes (Kazdin, 2001), defined as whether the intervention led to noticeable improvements in parent–child relationship quality (e.g., parents perceiving a closer parent–child relationship). Improvement in quantitative studies was defined as: statistically significant (p < .05) increases from pre- to post-intervention (quasi-experimental designs) or higher relationship quality in the intervention than control group (concurrent cohort or randomized experiment designs); a clear trend indicating clinically significant improvement (even if

not reaching statistical significance) for the aforementioned study designs; or a majority of participants (i.e., 75% or more) reporting improved relationship outcomes post-intervention on descriptive statistics.
Studies were rated as “Very Effective” if study authors reported clinically meaningful improvements for a majority (i.e., at least 75%) of participants on all aspects of the parent–child relationship overall in qualitative designs, or if improvements were reported on all overall and a majority of subscale scores in quantitative designs. Studies were rated as “Somewhat Effective” if author/s reported no improvement for a majority of participants on one or more aspects of the parent–child relationship overall in qualitative designs (e.g., parental sensitivity was described as unchanged for four out of five participants after intervention) or if any overall scores and/or a majority of subscale scores did not show improvement in quantitative designs. Although the rating refers to an individual study rather than all studies exploring an intervention, studies rated as Somewhat Effective are labeled as “Somewhat Effective interventions” where appropriate throughout the paper. A  classification of “Not Effective” was deemed unnecessary, as all studies demonstrated some effectiveness. For mixed-methods studies where the rating was discrepant between quantitative and qualitative components of the study, the overall rating was based on the aspect of the study rated as lower in effectiveness. No distinctions were made regarding the source of findings (e.g., parental self-report; observed changes) for the effectiveness assessment.

sections.heading: Data Extraction and Narrative Synthesis
sections.text:
Data extraction tables were developed by the first author in consultation with the second and third authors. The first author extracted main themes in qualitative studies from reported themes and/or descriptions of change due to intervention. Some study authors clearly described main themes theorizing about changes in the parent–child relationship; however, the authors of other studies did not clearly identify and/or describe the main themes. When main themes were unclear, attachment-related psychological frameworks (e.g., maternal sensitivity [Ainsworth et  al., 1978]) were used to interpret qualitative descriptions of change and identify attachment-related behaviors described in the original papers

(e.g., quality of parental responses to their child being identified as parental sensitivity).
The outcomes and main themes were synthesized according to four categories which emerged during the synthesis process. Parent–child relationship findings were synthesized to respond to the first study aim. Parental mental health and children’s emotional and behavioral functioning were included because they may relate to, impact, and/or mediate changes in parent–child attachment (Schechter & Willheim, 2009; Sroufe 2005). Other outcomes, particularly intervention acceptability and parents’ use of music techniques outside of sessions, were also explored as they may influence or reflect engagement in interventions and could thereby contribute to parent–child relationship changes (Hackworth et al., 2018).
The analytic strategy to synthesize change processes was developed by the first and second authors. The first author identified qualitative data and discussion sections of quantitative articles which speculated about change processes, and recorded descriptions of change processes from these studies in word processing documents. The first author developed main themes by identifying descriptions of change consistent with attachment theory, with assistance from the second author. Consensus about main themes was reached following discussion between the first and second authors. Themes directly related to attachment, those evident in multiple studies and/or described in detail were given greater emphasis when reporting findings than themes reported infrequently (e.g., in one study) and/or with minimal detail. No studies which met review criteria included statistical analyses of change processes (e.g., moderation, mediation, or regression analyses); thus, findings presented are derived from qualitative data and theorizing in the discussion sections of quantitative studies, which provide a basis for preliminary exploration about how music interventions may have facilitated parent–child relationship changes.

For ease of reading, studies are referred to by number hereafter.
Quality assessment No Randomized Controlled Trials (Level 1 evidence for effectiveness) met review criteria, and the only randomized experiment did not include baseline measures (9). Designs assessing effectiveness included eight quasi-experimental studies (Level 2) and one concurrent cohort study (Level 3), although there was a higher proportion (50% of included studies) of case studies (n = 13; Level 4). Evidence for meaningfulness identified no Level 1 or Level 2 evidence, with single qualitative studies being the only design identified (n = 9, some of which were also case studies; Level 3). Qualitative designs were generally rated as higher quality than quantitative designs, with one case study (20) and two qualitative studies (22, 23)  receiving a rating of Strong. The highest rating of a quantitative study was Medium–Strong (8, the concurrent cohort study) and all other quantitative designs (e.g., quasi-experiments) were rated as Medium or Weak, meaning that no Level 1 or 2 evidence for effectiveness or meaningfulness was rated as Strong. Methodological weaknesses in quantitative designs included that only three studies used validated relationship outcome measures (1, 8, 9)  only two studies included a control group receiving standard care (8, 9). The literature base was small (N  =  23 studies; 15 unique interventions). Considered together, these findings indicate that the quality of the body of evidence is relatively weak overall.

Four interventions were conducted in Australia (5, 6, 13–211), two in the United States (2, 9), two in England (7, 10), and one each in Scotland (4), Italy (8), and Belgium (12). Nine interventions involved participants who were vulnerable or at-risk for various reasons, including: parenting, bonding, interaction, and/or attachment difficulties (7, 13, 14, 16; Oldfield & Bunce, 2001); socioeconomic disadvantage (e.g., low income; 2, 6, 11, 13, 14, 16, 22); single (11, 13–16) or young parents (6, 13–16); current and/or historical substance misuse (4, 13, 14)  or maternal mental illness, including bipolar (3) or depression (12, 22, 23); parent and/or child trauma history (e.g., domestic violence; 13, 14, 16, 22, 23); child behavioral problems (7, 16; Oldfield & Bunce, 2001); young women in crisis (13–16); and/or being part of a cultural minority (e.g., Indigenous Australians, non-English speaking background; 13, 14, 16, 17). Six interventions involved participants from the general population in prevention studies (1, 5, 8–10, 18–21). Settings included medical or hospital (2, 8, 9, 12), community agency (5, 6, 13–17) or center (10), participant’s homes (4, 18–22), a University-affiliated clinic (22, 23), a shared living facility (11), a children’s unit (7), and two studies did not specify (1, 3).

Outcomes assessment Parental self-report was used to assess outcomes in most studies. Nine studies used parental selfreport questionnaires (1, 2, 6–10, 14, 15). Three studies used validated measures: the Mother-to-Infant Bonding Scale (MIBS; 8), the Kessler 10 (6), and the Edinburgh Postnatal Depression Scale (9). A  fourth study used items from the Child Rearing Questionnaire and Parental Perceptions and Behaviors Scale (6). The remaining studies used interventionist- or researcherdesigned questionnaires to determine parent–child relationship changes (2, 15), maternal relaxation (2), child behavior changes (7), satisfaction with the intervention (2, 6), effects of music improvisation (10), and music use at home (15), and qualitative parent comments about child behavior, parenting and parent– child relationship changes, and experiences of music and/or intervention were also collected via questionnaire (1, 2, 7, 10, 14). Other sources of parent feedback included written comments (17) informal discussions with parents (3–5, 9, 11, 13–15, 17), parent consultations (22, 23), parent journal or diary (18– 23), and structured (8, 9)  or semi-structured interviews with parents (10, 18–23).
Structured quantitative observational analyses were used in five studies. Only two used validated measures: the Indicator of Parent– Child Interaction and Early Communication Indicator (1), and the Looking, Touching, Talking and Smiling (LoTTS) Parent–Infant Interaction Coding Scale (9). Three studies used other observational analyses, including a microanalytic video analysis of intersubjective moments (12), an interventionist observation checklist (6), and a video coding scheme of parent and child behaviors (7). Qualitative observations such as therapist observations, notes and diaries (3, 4, 11, 14–16, 22, 23), and video review of sessions (10, 11, 22, 23) were used to evaluate six interventions. No studies measured parent–child attachment quality using self-report or observational measures.
Of the 10 interventions evaluated using quantitative research designs, pre- and post-intervention data was collected in six (1, 6, 8, 12, 18–23) and post-intervention data only was collected in four (2, 7, 9, 10). Formal follow-up was included in only one study at 48 hours, and 1, 2, and 3 months after birth (8). Follow-up longer than 3 months was not reported in any study.

Outcomes and main themes  Parenting and parent–child relationship findings. All studies reported parent–child relationship improvements, including in attachment-related outcomes. Studies comparing intervention to control conditions found significantly greater observed maternal warmth and responsiveness at 6 weeks postpartum (9) and motherreported bonding (i.e., the process of developing a connection or bond between parent and child; Bowlby, 1969) at 3  months postpartum (8). Significantly greater parental sensitivity (defined as “awareness of the child’s signals,” 6, p.  229), engagement, acceptance, and child responsiveness to their parent (6); occurrence, quality, and duration of intersubjectivity (i.e., reciprocal mother–infant interactions, including shared attention and mutual responsiveness; 12); and parent facilitation and child engagement parent-child interaction (1) were observed from baseline to post-intervention in quasi-experimental designs. Additionally, parents reported reduced parenting irritability from baseline to post-intervention in one study (6). Case and qualitative studies found improved parent–child interactions (1, 4, 5, 10, 13–17, 22, 23), child initiation of interactions with her mother (23), bonding (2, 9, 14, 18–23), maternal responsiveness and/or sensitivity (11, 15), parent-child attunement (2, 11, 18–23), intersubjectivity (11), parent-child co-regulation (including repair of negative emotions and/or mutual positive states; 5, 11, 22), and maternal representations of her child (7). Two studies reported improved father–child relationship quality (3, 22). No studies measured attachment security as an outcome.
Eighteen studies were rated as Very Effective for supporting the parent–child relationship. Five studies were rated as Somewhat Effective for the following reasons: not all aspects of parent–child interactions improved (1); parental warmth did not improve (6); parenting difficulties (e.g., difficulties setting limits with the child) were not resolved (3); a mother repeatedly did not acknowledge her child’s negative feelings (23); and only 53% of parents felt closer to their child (15).
Parental mental health and wellbeing findings. Findings suggested improved parental mental health outcomes due to music interventions, which theoretically could have contributed to improved parent–child attachment quality (Schechter & Willheim, 2009). One study found significantly lower perceived maternal stress on one of two measures at 1  month postpartum for intervention compared to control group participants (8), while another study found significant improvements in self-reported parental mental health from pre- to post-intervention (6). Maternal self-report and interventionist observations suggested increased positive feelings (e.g., joy, pride, relief, calmness, relaxation; 2, 4, 5, 10, 13, 15, 16, 18–21) and reduced stress and anxiety symptoms due to intervention (18–21). Two studies reported no significant differences between intervention and control conditions on some or all parent outcomes (8, 9).
Children’s emotional and behavioral findings. Studies reported improved child outcomes due to music interventions, which theoretically could have occurred because of parent–child relationship improvements and/or because improved child outcomes could have contributed to parent–child relationship changes (Sroufe, 2005). Child outcomes were reported in 12 interventions (1–6, 8–10, 13–22), with 11 reporting improvements. One study found significantly less crying at 1 month, neonatal colic at 1 and 2 months, and overnight waking at 2 months postpartum (8), and another found significantly lower weekly mean crying time over 6 weeks (r = 0.7; 9), in intervention compared to control conditions. Parent report and therapist observations suggested that infants went to sleep and settled more quickly (13–15, 18–21), children were more relaxed, calmer and soothed, and less distressed and irritable (2, 4, 5, 10, 13–15, 18–22), children improved in social, communication, play, and other developmental outcomes (6, 13–17), and child behavioral problems, tantrums, and asthma attacks reduced (3). Three studies reported no significant changes on some or all child outcomes (1, 6, 8).
Other findings. Findings suggested high levels of enjoyment, satisfaction, engagement, and intervention use, which theoretically could have contributed to improved parent–child relationship outcomes (Hackworth et al., 2018). Parent participants reported self and child enjoyment (5, 10, 13–15, 20) and high satisfaction with music interventions (2, 6). One study found significant increases in child engagement from pre- to post-intervention (1), and high parent and child engagement was observed during sessions in another study (7). Supplementary Table 3 presents intervention characteristics, including interventionist, aim/s, format, number, length and frequency of sessions, child target age, intervention name, music and other techniques, and control condition intervention (if applicable).
Population Music interventions facilitated improved parent– child relationships with children aged from birth to 5  years old, indicating they are suitable for supporting parent–child relationships with children within this age range. Most Somewhat Effective interventions involved children from birth to 5 years old and various caregivers (1, 3, 6, 15), although one of these studies involved a mother-toddler dyad (child aged 3-years-old; 23). All five interventions involving mother-infant dyads (infants aged up to 2-years-old) were rated as Very Effective (2, 8, 9, 12, 18–21). This suggests that music interventions with mother–infant dyads may improve relationship outcomes more consistently than interventions with other populations.
Intervention aims Focusing specifically on attachment did not appear to enhance relationship outcomes. Only five interventions aimed to strengthen attachment (4, 6, 9, 15, 23), three of which were rated as Somewhat Effective (6, 15, 23), while other interventions focused on different relationship aims. Interventions aiming exclusively to improve parent-child relationships and parenting appeared to lead to improved relationship quality more consistently than those with multiple aims, as all six studies focused on relationship and parenting aim/s only were rated as Very Effective (4, 7, 10–12, 22). Most interventions also aimed to improve child development (n = 9; 1, 3, 5, 6, 8, 9, 13–21, 23) and/or parental mental health (n = 5; 2, 6, 8, 16, 18–21). Twelve studies with multiple aims were rated as Very Effective (2, 5, 8, 9, 13, 14, 16–21); however, all

It is possible that some interventions with multiple aims were less targeted, which may have decreased their effectiveness for improving the parent–child relationship; however, given that most studies with multiple aims were rated as Very Effective, it is likely that other factors contributed to some of these interventions being rated as Somewhat Effective.
Interventionists Findings suggested that interventions delivered by music therapists, allied health professionals and mother-mediated music therapy interventions supported parent–child relationship outcomes. Most interventions were delivered by music therapists (n =13), although allied health professionals delivered two interventions (8, 12) and assisted with two of the 13 music therapy interventions (4, 7). Additionally, two music therapy interventions involved mother-mediated delivery (9, 18–21). All interventions involving allied health professionals (n = 4) and mother-mediated interventions (n  =  2) were rated as Very Effective. Nine studies of interventions delivered by music therapists were rated as Very Effective (2, 5, 10, 11, 13, 14, 22) and five were rated as Somewhat Effective (1, 3, 6, 15, 23).
Mode of delivery Nine interventions were delivered to a group (1, 5–8, 10–17), while six were delivered to one or more individual families or dyads (2–4, 9, 18–23). Effectiveness of an intervention did not appear to be impacted by mode of delivery, as Somewhat Effective interventions included three group (1, 6, 15) and two interventions delivered to individual dyads (3, 23).
Number of sessions The number of sessions ranged from 1 to 14 (M  =  6.7). All single session interventions were rated as Very Effective (2, 9, 18–21) and Somewhat Effective interventions involved 4–10 sessions (1, 3, 6, 15, 23). These ratings suggest that brief music interventions may be equally or more effective for improving parent–child relationships than longer interventions; however, all single session interventions focused on mother–infant dyads and two were mother-mediated, making it unclear whether the single session format or other intervention features contributed to relationship outcomes.

sections.heading: Change Processes
sections.text:
Mothers reported in interviews that a lullaby singing intervention reminded them to observe their infant’s responses, which encouraged maternal reflection, increased mothers’ understanding of their infant’s cues, and led to mothers selecting and/or modifying musical techniques to meet their infant’s needs. Lullaby singing was described as calming mothers and infants and supporting infants’ sleep, which decreased mothers’ stress and improved their confidence (18–21). In case- and interview-based studies, vocal interventions (e.g., singing, humming) accompanied with multimodal stimulation (e.g., rhythmic patting, rocking, stroking, walking, and/or swaying) were described as settling infants, decreasing infant distress, and/or inducing sleep, which sometimes led to positive feelings for mothers (4, 13–15, 19–21).
Authors of two quantitative studies postulated about processes which may have contributed to stronger relationship outcomes for dyads participating in a music intervention than a control condition (8, 9). The “expressiveness and intimacy” (8, p. e219) of lullaby singing may have contributed to significantly greater mother-reported bonding at 3  months postpartum for lullaby singing intervention participants compared to a control group. Lullaby singing may have facilitated infant relaxation and made

it easier for mothers to calm their infants, as intervention participants also reported significantly lower frequency of crying episodes in the first month postpartum than control participants (8). Mothers participating in a contingent lullaby singing intervention reported significantly lower infant crying than mothers in a control condition, which may have contributed to significantly higher maternal responsiveness and warmth and better mother–infant interactions for intervention than control participants, in addition to possibly improving maternal self-care, lowering maternal stress, and increasing maternal rest (9).
Inferences about change processes were explored in studies using qualitative analysis of session videos (10, 11, 22, 23), therapist notes (11, 22, 23), and parent interviews (10, 22, 23). In two studies exploring one intervention, an author described that singing, songwriting, and music-assisted relaxation supported intimacy and connection; singing, songwriting, and instrument playing facilitated exploration through musical play; and singing, instrument playing, and musical games facilitated parent–child affection with 3–5 year old children (22, 23). Three studies reported that music techniques (instrument playing and improvisation, improvised singing [sometimes with dancing], and musical games) facilitated parent–child attunement with 2–5-year-old children (10, 11, 22). Instrumental improvisation was reported to facilitate mothers’ observation of their child’s responses (10-month-old infant, 10; child aged between 2 and 4 years old; 11) and a mother following her 2 year old child’s responses to music (10).

sections.heading: Discussion
sections.text:
The aim of this systematic review was to locate and synthesize peer-reviewed literature evaluating the effects of music interventions on parent–child attachment-related outcomes and processes with typically developing children aged from birth to 5 years old. The aims of the review were to determine whether interventions improved attachment-related outcomes; to identify characteristics of music interventions which may support a more secure attachment; and to describe the processes by which music techniques may improve attachment-related outcomes. Twenty-three articles describing 15 unique music interventions met review criteria, involving approximately 809–817 parent–child dyads.

sections.heading: Attachment-related Outcomes
sections.text:
No studies included in the review measured attachment security as an outcome, meaning that clear conclusions about whether music interventions increase attachment security cannot be drawn. Nonetheless, all interventions showed at least some effectiveness for improving attachment-related outcomes, such as bonding, interaction quality, emotional co-regulation, and parental sensitivity (1–23). Music interventions were also associated with improved child emotional, developmental, and behavioral outcomes (2–6, 8–10, 13–22) and parental mental health and wellbeing (2, 4–6, 8, 10, 18–21). Findings suggest that music interventions have advantages such as participant enjoyment (5, 10, 13–15, 20) and high parental satisfaction (2, 6), which could have enhanced engagement in intervention and thereby contributed to improved parent–child relationship quality (Hackworth et al., 2018).
Music interventions delivered antenatally or during early infancy were associated with positive relationship outcomes (2, 4, 8, 9, 18–21), including higher mother-reported bonding (8) and observed maternal warmth and sensitivity (9) in intervention than control conditions. Findings of a meta-analysis suggests that there are fewer effective interventions for supporting parent–infant attachment for infants 6 months old and younger than for older infants (Bakermans-Kranenburg et  al., 2003). Music interventions may address a gap in available interventions, as they have features which may make them suitable for use from birth, such as infants’ inherent musicality and the musical qualities of mother–infant interactions (Edwards, 2011; Malloch, 1999). Mother-mediated singing interventions may be especially suited, as they can be integrated into infants’ everyday routines at home and could be brief and cost-effective (e.g., 9).
Music interventions also appeared to support parent–child relationship outcomes (e.g., attunement; emotional closeness) and child exploration through musical play for 2 to 5 year old children (3, 7, 10, 11, 22, 23). These findings suggest that music interventions supported important aspects of parent–child attachment during toddlerhood, including autonomy development through exploration and the child’s emotional closeness to their parent (Lieberman, 1992). Additionally, two studies reported improved

father–child relationship quality with children aged 3–5  years old (3, 22), suggesting that music interventions are suited to supporting both mother–child and father–child relationships with children this age.

sections.heading: Music Techniques and Change Processes
sections.text:
Inferences about change processes were based on interpreting findings of included studies from the perspective of attachment theory, in order to speculate about how music interventions could increase attachment security and guide future research to test these postulations. One study found greater maternal responsiveness (an aspect of sensitivity; Nicholls & Kirkland, 1996) in a lullaby singing intervention than a control group (9), and another reported improved parental sensitivity from pre- to post-intervention (6). Metaanalytic evidence indicates that interventions targeting maternal sensitivity increase parent–child attachment security (BakermansKranenburg et al., 2003), suggesting that improved parental sensitivity due to the music intervention may have enhanced attachment security.
Findings suggest that music techniques may have facilitated parent–child relationship improvements through intervening in Parental Reflective Functioning (PRF) in a similar way to psychological interventions not involving music. Lullaby singing (18–21) and instrumental improvisation (10, 11)  were reported to facilitate maternal observation of their infant or young child’s responses, which appeared to lead to sensitive maternal responses in at least one intervention (18–21). Some psychological interventions aiming to develop PRF encourage parents to observe their child’s behavior and reflect on the internal experiences potentially underlying their child’s behavior (Powell et al., 2014; Slade, 2007), which is a similar process to what reportedly occurred through music techniques. Lullaby singing may be particularly suited to supporting PRF, as it is believed to direct maternal attention to observing their infant’s responses and thereby encourages reflection on the infant’s behavior (Trehub et al., 1997), which is similar to what mothers described experiencing in a lullaby singing intervention (18–21).
Singing techniques appeared to support mother–infant co-regulation processes (5, 8, 9, 18–21), which also influence attachment security (Guo et al., 2015; Schore, 2001; Tronick, 2007).

Lullaby singing interventions were reported to support infant (4, 13–15, 8, 9, 18–21) and maternal self-regulation (18–21), and mothers participating in lullaby singing interventions reportedly found it easier to soothe their infants than those in control conditions (8, 9). Listening to their mother’s singing may have improved infants’ self-regulation. Additionally, the act of singing may have improved mothers’ ability to regulate their own emotions (Porges, 2011), which could have supported mothers to co-regulate their infants’ emotions (Schore, 2001; Slade, 2007). Rhythmic qualities of music may have also supported physiological regulation, especially when paired with movement and/or multimodal stimulation (Perry, 2009); therefore, multimodal stimulation with singing could have enhanced the regulatory effects of music for infants (4, 13–15, 18–21). Infant responses to music interventions (e.g., decreased crying) also appeared to contribute to improved maternal mental health and wellbeing (4, 9, 13–15, 18–21), and authors of one study proposed that less infant crying in the intervention group may have improved mother–infant interactions (9). These findings suggest that music intervention effects on the infant may lead to maternal and relationship improvements, although further research is needed to explore this possibility.
Findings suggested that interventions delivered by music therapists, allied health professionals, and mother-mediated music therapy interventions supported parent–child relationships. The mother-mediated interventions included in this review focused on singing with individual mother–infant dyads (9, 18–21) and both interventions delivered by allied health professionals involved group singing with either mother–infant dyads (12) or pregnant mothers (8). All interventions with mother–infant dyads were rated as Very Effective and singing interventions were generally associated with positive outcomes. Thus, it is unclear whether interventionist characteristics, such as the training of allied health professionals or the potential of mothers using music techniques in-between sessions, contributed to parent–child relationship outcomes. Future research could explore whether the interventionist impacts outcomes in comparable interventions. Additionally, interventions delivered by allied health professionals involved comparatively simple musical techniques (e.g., singing), suggesting that more complex techniques (e.g., songwriting) are within the scope of music therapists rather than

allied health professionals. Future research could explore which types of music techniques are suitable for a range of health professionals to implement, and which techniques are more suitable for music therapists to implement.
Clinical Implications
Singing was used in all included interventions, suggesting that it is a central music technique used to support parent–child attachment. Instrument playing also appeared to facilitate parent–child relationship improvements; however, interventions including instrument playing appeared to improve relationship quality less consistently than those involving singing only. Findings suggest that interventionists could support parent–child dyads to develop a more secure attachment by facilitating parental observation of their child’s cues and supporting parents to respond sensitively to their child during music-making. Interventions with young infants and their parents could also focus on supporting emotional co-regulation using singing and multimodal stimulation. Music interventions were shown to be adaptable to various settings, flexible depending on the client’s needs, and suitable for implementation by music therapists and allied health professionals. Findings suggest that music interventions could be used for both prevention and intervention. The acceptability of music interventions may make them especially suitable for dyads where engagement, attendance, or retention in interventions has been difficult.

sections.heading: Limitations and Future Directions
sections.text:
Multidisciplinary collaboration between music therapists and allied health professionals may support the development, evaluation, and implementation of music interventions to support parent– child attachment. Music therapy is a small discipline compared to some allied health professions; for example, there are currently 9,107 Board Certified Music Therapists in the United States and overseas (Certification Board for Music Therapists, 2020), while there were over 681,000 social workers employed in the United States in 2020 (U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, 2021). Thus, allied health professionals could support the dissemination of music interventions more widely within the community. Additionally, allied health professionals with expertise in parent–child attachment

(e.g., psychologists) could collaborate with music therapists to design music interventions targeting attachment processes (e.g., parental sensitivity) and assist with evaluating intervention effects using observational measures of attachment (e.g., the Strange Situation Procedure; Ainsworth et al., 1978; Main & Solomon, 1986). These contributions could support the development of attachmentspecific music interventions and strengthen the evidence base for music interventions aiming to improve parent–child attachment.
Future studies evaluating music interventions aiming to support parent–child attachment could employ more rigorous research designs (e.g., Randomized Controlled Trials) than studies included in the present review, in order to assess intervention effects and to compare music to other intervention types. Studies could evaluate interventions using validated parent–child relationship outcome measures alongside measures aiming to capture other salient outcomes (e.g., emotional regulation) and use longitudinal follow-up to explore long-term effects, similar to Persico and colleagues (2017). Studies could also statistically analyze change processes (e.g., using mediation, moderation, and/or regression analyses) in order to better understand attachment-related change processes in music interventions.
Participant characteristics limit the generalizability of findings. Most participating caregivers were mothers, few fathers participated, and no studies involved other caregivers (e.g., adoptive parents) or father–child dyads with children under 3  years old. Most studies exploring change processes with infants involved participants not identified as vulnerable or at-risk (8, 9, 18–21). Additionally, Western participants were overrepresented, and no studies were published from non-Western countries. Thus, music intervention effects and change processes need to be evaluated with a more diverse range of participants, including parent–child dyads with insecure attachment. Research is also needed to synthesize the existing evidence and design attachment interventions for children with additional needs, given that studies involving this population were excluded from this review.
Limitations of this review include using researcher-designed criteria to classify study quality and effectiveness, which involved some subjectivity in the rating process. Multiple authors were involved in the quality and effectiveness assessments and data synthesis process; however, potential biases were not controlled for by inter-rater reliability. Additionally, publication bias and/or selective reporting

of results were not assessed in this review. A future review could employ more rigorous methodology, including inter-rater reliability and assessing for publication bias (particularly if the review also includes gray literature), which may allow researchers to draw clearer conclusions about the effects of music interventions on parent– child attachment security. However, more research evaluating music interventions to support parent–child attachment must be conducted before such a review is possible or warranted.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: Music interventions have unique qualities which make them suitable for supporting parent–child attachment in early childhood. Findings suggest that music interventions improve attachment-related outcomes, such as bonding, emotional co-regulation, interaction quality, and parental sensitivity. Techniques such as singing, instrument playing, and movement or multimodal stimulation with music appear to support parent–child relationship quality. Music interventions may facilitate parent–child relationship changes through supporting psychological processes, such as parental sensitivity, reflective functioning, and emotional co-regulation. Findings suggest that participants perceived music interventions as acceptable, which may enhance participant engagement in interventions and could thereby improve parent–child relationship outcomes. Music interventions aiming to improve attachment quality need to be designed and evaluated, as few included interventions focused on improving attachment quality and no studies included measures of parent–child attachment quality. Additionally, the existing evidence base is relatively small and weak in quality, indicating that further research is required to determine whether music interventions impact attachment security and to elucidate processes through which relationship changes occur. These advances could allow clearer conclusions to be drawn about whether music interventions support attachment security and may enable interventionists to use music interventions to remediate parent–child attachment difficulties more effectively.
